text: I wonder if it would be completely insane to allow all binary operators to also be defined as macros?  seems like it would have a ton of really nice uses, but on the other hand it could get horribly confusing if people don't use this power responsibly

text: it's true that it's not always used that well in math and physics papers, but usually not to the degree that programming languages abuse it.  In physics sometimes they use `\equiv` as "defined as" which isn't quite as bad as `=` in programming languages (because, for one, it always guarantees the arguments are strictly equal), but it's still kind of weird

text:
```julia> x = 1                                       
1                                                  
                                                   
julia> x := 4                                      
ERROR: syntax: unsupported assignment operator ":="
Stacktrace:                                        
 [1] top-level scope                               
   @ REPL[7]:1                                     ```

text:
I was raised in my physics classes to use `:=` for assignment and to keep it distinct from `=`. sometimes we were sloppy, but usually people kept to that convention when it mattered. 

I like it because it’s ASCII and visually asymmetric and only one extra character
